head.title: Highly Efficient Ethenolysis and Propenolysis of Methyl Oleate Catalyzed by Abnormal N-Heterocyclic Carbene Ruthenium Complexes in Combination with a Phosphine–Copper Cocatalyst | ACS Catalysis

meta.content: Highly Efficient Ethenolysis and Propenolysis of Methyl Oleate Catalyzed by Abnormal N-Heterocyclic Carbene Ruthenium Complexes in Combination with a Phosphine–Copper Cocatalyst

Fluorinated imidazo[1,5-a]pyridine abnormal carbene ruthenium complexes (F-aImPy–Ru) with a tricyclohexylphosphine copper chloride (Cy3P–CuCl) cocatalyst were developed for the ethenolysis/propenolysis of methyl oleate. These catalysts showed remarkable catalytic efficiencies (turnover numbers of 100,000 for ethenolysis and 200,000 for propenolysis) and excellent α-olefin selectivity (up to 99%). A computational study indicated that the energy barrier of the β-hydride elimination pathway in the presence of a phosphine–copper cocatalyst is higher than that in the absence of the cocatalyst, which might contribute to the improved longevity of the ruthenium catalyst in the reaction.

div.span: Supporting Info (1)
SUBJECTS:

div.p:
Fluorinated imidazo[1,5-
a
]pyridine abnormal carbene ruthenium complexes (F-aImPy–Ru) with a tricyclohexylphosphine copper chloride (Cy
3
P–CuCl) cocatalyst were developed for the ethenolysis/propenolysis of methyl oleate. These catalysts showed remarkable catalytic efficiencies (turnover numbers of 100,000 for ethenolysis and 200,000 for propenolysis) and excellent α-olefin selectivity (up to 99%). A computational study indicated that the energy barrier of the β-hydride elimination pathway in the presence of a phosphine–copper cocatalyst is higher than that in the absence of the cocatalyst, which might contribute to the improved longevity of the ruthenium catalyst in the reaction.

div.span: KEYWORDS:
ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
The formation of carbon–carbon double bonds
via
olefin metathesis reactions
(1)
has been widely applied in synthetic applications such as pharmaceuticals, petrochemicals, fine chemicals, and polymers.
(2)
Highly efficient and selective catalysts for various challenging metathesis reactions have been developed. Nevertheless, the ethenolysis reaction (cross-metathesis with ethylene) remains relatively underdeveloped (
Scheme 1
a).
(3)
Ethenolysis has attracted much attention as an atom-economical transformation, enabling the eco-friendly conversion of renewable seed oil feedstocks (
e.g.
, fatty acid methyl esters, FAMEs)
(4)
into value-added chemicals such as linear α-olefins. Linear α-olefins are pivotal precursors for poly(α-olefins).
(5)
To become an economically viable industrial process, a turnover number (TON) of over 35,000 should be achieved for specialty chemical synthesis and a TON of at least 50,000 is required for commodity chemical production.
(3h)
Notably, the stability of ruthenium methylidene
A
and ruthenacyclobutane
B
is closely related to catalyst performance, as such intermediates are prone to decompose (
e.g.
, β-hydride elimination) (
Scheme 1
b).
(6)
Electronic and steric modifications of ligands often lead to enhanced activities, selectivities, and stabilities of metal complexes.
(7)
Notably, the use of additives can also improve catalyst activity and stability in metathesis reactions.
(8)
Scheme 1. (a) Ethenolysis of Methyl Oleate and (b) Key Intermediates

The second-generation Grubbs catalyst (
1
), in which the phosphine ligand in the first-generation Grubbs catalyst, RuCl
2
(PCy
3
)
2
(═CHPh), was replaced with a
N
-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ligand, offered dramatically improved metathesis catalytic activity.
(9)
The introduction of an oxygen-chelated benzylidene ligand in the Hoveyda–Grubbs catalyst (
2
)
(10)
resulted in a significant improvement in catalyst stability. Although ruthenium catalysts bearing symmetrical NHCs (such as 1,3-bis(2,4,6-trimethylphenyl)-4,5-dihydroimidazol-2-ylidene, SIMes) have been extensively used for a long time, their selectivities in ethenolysis are quite low (approximately 33% for
1
and
2
in
Figure
1
). The low selectivities were attributed to a “productive” metathesis event including self-metathesis and secondary metathesis in which the ruthenium alkylidene intermediate undergoes a cross-metathesis reaction with other internal olefins or α-olefin products.
(3g,11)
Sterically unsymmetrical frameworks (
3–6
)
(12)
emerged as ligands of choice for highly α-olefin-selective ethenolysis.
(13)
In particular, cyclic-alkyl-amino-carbene (CAAC)–ruthenium catalysts (
4
) exhibit excellent catalytic activities (TONs of up to 340,000 at 1 ppm catalyst loading) (
Figure
1
).
(14)
CAACs,
(15)
which are stronger donating ligands than NHCs, are believed to stabilize the key intermediates.
(6a)
To date, TONs greater than 50,000 have been achieved with CAAC-ligated ruthenium catalysts.
(14,16)

div.p: Figure 1. Selected ruthenium-based metathesis catalysts.

div.div:
Abnormal NHCs (
a
NHCs), which feature “unusual” bonding between the metal and the NHC ligand,
(17)
have been utilized in various catalytic transformations,
(18)
as they possess exceptional electron-donating ability. Examples of
a
NHC–ruthenium catalysts (
Figure
2
a) have been reported; abnormal triazolylidene ligands were introduced in ruthenium benzylidene complexes
7a
, and latent ruthenium catalysts
7b
were shown to be initiated by Brønsted acids.
(19)
Interestingly, triazolium-based
a
NHCs can act as both nonlabile and dissociable ligands presumably because of their unique electronic properties. In 2005, the Lassaletta group demonstrated that imidazo[1,5-
a
]pyridinium salts could be used as abnormal carbene precursors (
a
ImPy)
via
C1 deprotonation.
(20)
We noticed that
a
ImPy ligands have an unsymmetrical structure, and the desired steric demands could be achieved by a substituent close to a metal center. Thus, we envisioned that fluorinated
abnormal
imidazo[1,5-
a
]pyridinium carbenes could be appropriate ligand candidates for ethenolysis (
Figure
2
b). To the best of our knowledge, examples of
a
ImPy–ruthenium metathesis catalysts have not been reported.
(21)
Furthermore, we serendipitously discovered that the use of a phosphine–copper chloride complex dramatically improved the catalytic performance of the ruthenium catalysts. Herein, we describe fluorinated imidazo[1,5-
a
]pyridine abnormal carbene ruthenium catalysts (F-
a
ImPy–Ru,
10
) in combination with the tricyclohexylphosphine–copper chloride (Cy
3
P–CuCl) cocatalyst for the ethenolysis/propenolysis of methyl oleate. Ruthenium catalysts
10
showed remarkable catalytic efficiencies (TONs of 100,000 for ethenolysis and 200,000 for propenolysis) and excellent α-olefin selectivity (up to 99%). Computational studies indicate that the phosphine–copper chloride complex could help to stabilize the ruthenium intermediate and enhance the metathesis catalytic activity.

div.p:
Figure 2. Examples of
a
NHC–Ru complexes, fluorinated ImPy–Ru complex
9
(ref
(22)
), and fluorinated
a
ImPy–Ru complexes
10
.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
The energy levels of the highest occupied molecular orbitals (HOMOs) in the F-ImPy and F-
a
ImPy ligands were calculated by density functional theory (DFT). The geometries of the free ligands in their ground states were optimized at the B3LYP/def2-TZVPP level.
(23)
The HOMOs of the free ligand structures in NHC, CAAC, F-ImPy, and F-
a
ImPy display σ-orbitals and π-donor orbitals characteristic of carbene carbon centers (
Figure
3
). We found that the energy levels of the σ-orbital (HOMO-1) and π-orbital (HOMO) of F-
a
ImPy were significantly higher (−5.34 and −5.36 eV) than those of NHC (−5.62 eV) and F-ImPy (−5.48 and −6.16 eV) and slightly lower than those of CAAC (−5.20 eV). The singlet–triplet gap (Δ
E
ST,
51.1 kcal mol
–1
) of F-
a
ImPy was comparable to that of CAAC (48.3 kcal mol
–1
), but it was much smaller than that of NHC (72.7 kcal mol
–1
). These calculation results suggest that F-
a
ImPy is a strongly electron-donating ligand similar to CAAC.

div.p:
Figure 3. Comparison of the calculated HOMO (eV) levels and Δ
E
ST
(kcal mol
–1
) values between NHC, CAAC, F-ImPy, and F-
a
ImPy at the B3LYP/def2-TZVPP level.
N
-Methyl groups were used instead of
N
-aryl groups for simplicity.

div.div:
Encouraged by the DFT calculation results, we prepared a series of F-
a
ImPy ligand precursors (
8a–8l
) following the method reported by Shi and co-workers (
Scheme S1
).
(24)
Then, the corresponding F-
a
ImPy–Ru complexes (
10a
–
10l
) were synthesized by C1 deprotonation of the imidazo[1,5-
a
]pyridinium salts, followed by reaction with RuCl
2
(PCy
3
) (═CH-
o
-O-
i
-PrC
6
H
4
) (
HG1
) (
Scheme 2
). Notably, substitution at the C3 position (
e.g.
, R
3
= aryl) was required for clean C1 deprotonation. Furthermore, the fluorine substituent at the C8 position seemed to play a crucial role in stabilizing the ruthenium catalyst, as the unsubstituted H-
a
ImPy–Ru complex was unstable. The same trend was observed with
normal
ImPy ruthenium catalyst
9
.
(22)
F-
a
ImPy–Ru complexes
10
were characterized by NMR spectroscopy, elemental analysis, high-resolution mass spectrometry, and X-ray crystallography analysis.

Scheme 2. Synthesis of F-
a
ImPy–Ru Complexes

The X-ray structures of complexes
10a
and
10k
showed a distorted square pyramidal geometry. The bond lengths and angles within the coordination sphere are similar to those of SIMes–Ru,
(10a)
CAAC–Ru,
(16g)
and normal F-ImPy–Ru
9
catalysts.
(22)
The % buried volume (%
V
Bur
) and topographic steric maps were also calculated using
SambVca 2.1
(
Figure
4
).
(25)
The %
V
Bur
values of the
abnormal
F-
a
ImPy carbene ligands of
10a
and
10k
(33.6%/34.0% and 32.6%) are similar to those of the
normal
F-ImPy carbene ligands of ruthenium catalyst
9
(32.8%, see Figure S1 in the
Supporting Information
). The quadrantal %
V
Bur
value patterns of F-
a
ImPy–Ru catalysts
10
are also similar to those of F-ImPy–Ru catalyst
9
and other ethenolysis-selective ruthenium catalysts, suggesting that the structurally unsymmetrical feature of ruthenium catalyst
10
could also result in high selectivity in ethenolysis.
(14,22)
The electronic property of the F-
a
ImPy ligands was evaluated by Tolman electronic parameter (TEP) analysis.

div.p:
Figure 4. X-ray structures of
10a
(a) and
10k
(b). %
V
Bur
values and topographic steric maps of
10a
(c) and
10k
(d). The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Selective bond lengths [Å] and angles [°] for
10a
, Ru–C1 = 1.96(1) Å, Ru═C27 = 1.81(1) Å, Ru–F1 = 3.007(6) Å, Ru–O1 = 2.301(7) Å, C7–C1–N1 = 101.3(8)°, C7–C1–Ru = 122.9(7)°, and Cl–Ru–Cl = 151.5(1)° and for
10k
, Ru–C1 = 1.964(6) Å, Ru═C27 = 1.830(5) Å, Ru–F1 = 2.994(3) Å, Ru–O1 = 2.301(7) Å, C2–C1–N1 = 101.3(4)°, C2–C1–Ru = 122.2(4)°, and Cl–Ru–Cl = 149.69(5)°.

div.div:
The [(F-
a
ImPy)Ir(CO)
2
Cl] complex was prepared, and the CO vibrational frequency was measured by infrared spectroscopy (
Scheme S2
). TEP analysis revealed that the F-
a
ImPy ligand (2044 cm
–1
) is a stronger donor than F-ImPy (2051 cm
–1
),
(22)
SIMes (2052 cm
–1
), CAAC (2046 cm
–1
), and an abnormal triazolylidene ligand (2046 cm
–1
).
(26)
The donating power of
abnormal
ImPy ligands is significantly higher than that of
normal
ImPy ligands. The use of a strong donating ligand is often critical for highly efficient metathesis.
(6a,14,16)

The catalytic performance of F-
a
ImPy–Ru complex
10a
was evaluated in the ethenolysis of methyl oleate
11
(
Table
1
). High catalytic activity (63% conversion) and excellent α-olefin selectivity (95%) over the self- and secondary-metathesis products (
12
and
13
vs
14
and
15
) were observed with the
abnormal
F-
a
ImPy–Ru catalyst
10a
(entry 1). Note that F-
a
ImPy–Ru
10a
is more active and selective than the corresponding
normal
F-ImPy–Ru complex
9
(entry 7).
(22)
Based on the TEP analysis results, the higher activity in ethenolysis can be attributed to the increased electron-donating power of F-
a
ImPy. During the initial stage of the reaction optimization, we serendipitously noticed that slightly impure
10a
showed a better conversion than highly pure
10a
at 10 ppm catalyst loading (entry 3
vs
entry 2). We hypothesized that the impurity might be tricyclohexylphosphine–copper chloride (Cy
3
P–CuCl), which could be generated from the CuCl added as a phosphine scavenger in the previous step.
(10)
As a control experiment, Cy
3
P–CuCl
16
was prepared from PCy
3
and CuCl in THF. The phosphine–copper chloride complex is known to have a dimeric structure,
(27)
and a catalytic amount of
16
(10 ppm) was prepared and added to the ethenolysis reaction. Gratifyingly, 46% conversion and a TON of 45,000 were observed, confirming our hypothesis. Thus, phosphine–copper chloride complex
16
dramatically influences the activity of the ruthenium catalyst (entry 4). When the loading of ruthenium–copper catalyst
10a
/
16
was lowered to 5 ppm/5 ppm and further to 3 ppm/3 ppm, the catalyst system remained remarkably efficient, showing TONs of 58,000 and 63,000, respectively (entries 5 and 6). Note that the ruthenium catalyst and the copper cocatalyst might be one of the best ethenolysis catalysts known to date, showing a high TON (>50,000) at a low catalyst loading (<10 ppm). Various copper–phosphine complexes, as well as other organic/inorganic additives, were tested to see if they provided similar beneficial effects, and Cy
3
P–CuCl
16
was found to be the best additive (see Tables S2 and S3 in the
Supporting Information
). The phosphine–copper chloride complex might slow the decomposition of the ruthenium intermediates.

Table 1. Ethenolysis of Methyl Oleate with the Developed Catalyst (
10a
)
a

Reaction conditions: catalyst (ppm), temperature (40 °C), C
2
H
4
(150 psi, 99.95% purity), and 3 h. The conversion and selectivity were determined by GC using tridecane as an internal standard.

Selectivity = 100 × (moles
12
+
13

12
+
13
) + (2 × moles of
14
+
15
)].
Yield = conversion × selectivity/100.

TON = yield × (initial moles
11
/moles catalyst)/100.
An impurity was present.
The reaction time was 6 h.

div.div:
The ligand structure of F-
a
ImPy–Ru complex
10a
(R
1
= R
2
=
i
-Pr, R
3
= Ph) for the ethenolysis of methyl oleate was further varied (
Table
2
). An excellent selectivity (>93%) was observed in all cases (
10a–10l
), and the structurally unsymmetrical feature of the F-
a
ImPy ligands could be responsible for the consistently high selectivities shown by all the catalysts. When the R
3
substituent was varied (
10b
–
10g
), the conversions were not mostly improved (14–21% conversions, entries 2, 3, 5, 6, and 7) except for
10d
(32% conversion, entry 4). Interestingly, the catalytic performance was significantly affected by the ortho-substituents of the
N
-aryl groups (R
1
and R
2
). The highest selectivity (>99%) was observed with
10h
(R
1
= R
2
= Et
2
CH−), although the conversion was slightly reduced (entry 8). The replacement of one isopropyl group with an
n
-propyl group (R
1
=
i
-Pr, R
2
=
n
-Pr) diminished both the conversion (17%) and selectivity (93%), presumably because of the decreased steric protection (entry 10). Nevertheless, the combination of a
t
-Bu group (R
1
) and an
n
-Pr group (R
2
) resulted in improved conversions (37% and 45%, entries 11 and 13), although the east side of %
V
Bur
values of
10k
(32.7%) were slightly lower than those of
10a
(35.05%/35.8%) (
Figure
4
). Ruthenium catalysts bearing a 4-F-Ph group at R
3
(
10d
,
10i
, and
10l
) exhibited higher TONs (62,000, 48,000, and 86,000, respectively) compared to the corresponding complexes with R
3
= Ph (
10a
,
10h
, and
10k
) (entries 4, 9, and 13
vs
entries 1, 8, and 11). Thus, the most efficient catalyst,
10l
(R
1
=
t
-Bu, R
2
=
n
-Pr, and R
3
= 4-F-Ph), demonstrated excellent selectivity (95%) and a remarkable TON (110,000) even at very low (3 ppm) catalyst loading (entry 14). Note that the remarkable catalytic performance shown by
10l
is comparable to that exhibited by CAAC–Ru
4a
in our conditions (entry 14
vs
entry 15). Furthermore, the addition of phosphine–copper chloride complex
16
also improved the TON of CAAC–Ru
4a
(150,000
vs
100,000, entry 16
vs
entry 15), implying that the cocatalyst effect could be more general.

Table 2. Ligand Structure Survey for the Ethenolysis of Methyl Oleate (
10a–10l
)
a

div.p:
Reaction conditions: catalyst (ppm), temperature (40 °C), C
2
H
4
(150 psi, 99.95% purity), and 3 h. The conversion and selectivity were determined by GC using tridecane as an internal standard.

Selectivity = 100 × (moles
12
+
13
)/[(moles
12
+

14

Yield = conversion × selectivity/100.

TON = yield × (initial moles
11

The reaction time was 6 h.

div.div:
To elucidate the effect of a cocatalyst, we conducted time-course experiments using gas chromatography (GC) (
Figure
5
). When 20 ppm of Cy
3
P–CuCl
16
was added along with 20 ppm of Ru catalyst
10l
, there was no significant difference in the conversions of methyl oleate in the early stage of the reaction. However, without using Cy
3
P–CuCl
16
, the conversion stalled as the reaction proceeded (orange curve). Cy
3
P–CuCl
16
seemed to extend the lifetime of the catalytically active ruthenium intermediate during the reaction (red curve). In contrast, when the loading of Ru catalyst
10l
was lowered to 10 ppm, the use of cocatalyst Cy
3
P–CuCl
16
made a profound difference; the ethenolysis reaction with the catalyst system (
10l
and
16
, 10 ppm each) retained most of its catalytic activity over a longer period (52% conversion, yellow curve), whereas the ethenolysis reaction with only the Ru catalyst (
10l,
10 ppm) rapidly slowed (19% conversion, green curve). The catalyst system was not considerably affected by the ratio of ruthenium and copper complexes, but interestingly, lowering the cocatalyst to 5 ppm was still efficient in the ethenolysis (blue curve). Note that the use of cocatalyst Cy
3
P–CuCl
16
was highly effective at lower catalyst loadings. These results might be explained by Cy
3
P–CuCl
16
, inhibiting the deactivation of the ruthenium catalyst. This curious effect led us to wonder whether the copper cocatalyst could stabilize the catalytically active species.

div.p:
Figure 5. Reaction profiles for the ethenolysis of
11
with catalysts
10l
and
16
at loadings [Ru/Cu] of 20/20 ppm (red), 20/0 ppm (orange), 10/20 ppm (purple), 10/15 ppm (black), 10/10 (yellow), 10/5 ppm (blue), 10/0 ppm (green), and reaction conditions: temperature (40 °C), C
2
H
4
(150 psi).

div.div:
To rationalize the aforementioned experimental observations, the energies of intermediates (
A–E
) and transition states (
TS
) were calculated by DFT (
Figure
6
). Ruthenacyclobutane intermediates (
B
mcb
and
B
mcb
′
) are the resting state in the presence of excess ethylene (
Figure
6
).
(28)
From the ruthenacyclobutane resting states, two reaction pathways could be considered: an ethenolysis pathway (
B
mcb
→
TS
(
A–B
mcb
) →
A
→
TS
(
A–C
mcb
) →
C
mcb
) and a
β
-hydride elimination pathway (
B
mcb
→
TS
(
B
mcb
–E
) →
E
). The
β-
hydride elimination pathway could afford other isomerized byproducts. When the estimated Gibbs free energies of activation are compared, the ethenolysis pathway {Δ
G
⧧
= 13.5 kcal mol
–1
for
B
mcb
→
TS
(
A–C
mcb
)} should be favored over the
β
-hydride elimination pathway (Δ
G
⧧
= 25.7 kcal mol
–1
for
B
mcb
→
TS
(
B
mcb
–E
)). This calculation result is in accord with the fact that F-
a
ImPy–Ru catalysts did not afford isomerized (chain-walking) byproducts (Figure S4 in the
Supporting Information
). A similar trend is observed for the computed free energy profile in the presence of phosphine–copper chloride. The estimated Gibbs free energy of activation for the ethenolysis pathway {Δ
G
⧧
= 13.2 kcal mol
–1
for
B
mcb
′
→
TS
(
A′–C
mcb
′
)}is lower than that for the
β
-hydride elimination pathway {Δ
G
⧧
= 28.6 kcal mol
–1
for
B
mcb
′
→
TS
(
B
mcb
′
–E′
)}. Note that the ethenolysis pathway is more favored over the β-hydride elimination pathway when the phosphine–copper chloride is present (ΔΔ
G
⧧
= 15.4 kcal mol
–1
vs
ΔΔ
G
⧧
= 12.2 kcal mol
–1
). Therefore, DFT calculation suggests that the improved longevity of the ruthenium catalyst in the presence of copper cocatalyst might originate from the higher activation energy barrier for the β-hydride elimination pathway.

div.p:

–1
calculated at M06-D3/6-311++G(2df,2p) ≈ def2-TZVPP and SMD with toluene//M06-D3/6-31G(d,p) ≈ LanL2DZ and SMD with toluene of theory in blue for F-
a
ImPy–Ru and in red for F-
a
ImPy–Ru and Cy
3
P–CuCl.

div.div:
Alkenolysis, cross-metathesis with α-olefins (
i.e.
, propene or 1-butene), is known to be highly productive.
(3d,29)
The use of propylene as an ethylene surrogate led to a significant increase in the productivity of methyl 9-decenoate (
13
) with 1 ppm of ruthenium catalyst (a TON of 190,000) when soybean oil fatty acid methyl esters (soy FAMEs) were used after Magnesol treatment.
(3d)
The cross-metathesis of methyl oleate
11
with propylene (propenolysis) was examined with the catalyst system (
Table
3
). To our delight, the ruthenium catalyst with a copper cocatalyst (
10k
and
16
, 5 ppm) showed a high conversion (47%) with propylene (entry 1). At 3 ppm catalyst loading, the ruthenium catalysts were remarkably efficient (42% for
10k
and 50% for
10l
, entries 2 and 4). Again, TONs of over 100,000 were achieved with
10k
and
10l
at 1 ppm catalyst loading (entries 3 and 5). At lower pressure (80 psi),
10l
showed excellent productivity (a TON of 200,000) (entry 6). These results demonstrate that the ruthenium catalyst with a copper cocatalyst is highly efficient in propenolysis.

Table 3. Propenolysis of Methyl Oleate with Catalysts
10k
and
10l

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In summary, novel fluorinated imidazo[1,5-
a
]pyridine abnormal carbene ruthenium catalysts (F-
a
ImPy–Ru) and tricyclohexylphosphine–copper chloride (Cy
3
P–CuCl) cocatalyst were developed for the ethenolysis/propenolysis of methyl oleate. The catalyst system exhibited outstanding catalytic efficiency (TONs of up to 110,000) and excellent α-olefin selectivities (93–99%) in ethenolysis. Optimized ruthenium catalyst
10l
and copper cocatalyst
16
showed remarkable activity in propenolysis (TONs of up to 200,000). The computational study suggested that the enhanced lifetime of ruthenium catalyst in the presence of copper cocatalyst might originate from the increased activation energy barrier for the β-elimination pathway.

This is a review of papers published in the year 2017 that focus on the synthesis, reactivity, or properties of compds. contg. a carbon-transition metal double or triple bond. Highlights for the year 2017 include: (1) significant advances in the design of new precursors to carbene complex intermediates that serve as safer alternatives to potentially hazardous diazo compds., (2) continued vast employment of olefin metathesis for the synthesis of complex small mols. and polymers, including many examples of Z-selective and stereo-retentive reactions, (3) design of novel transformations employing metallacumulene intermediates, (4) prepn. of novel arom. ring systems incorporating transition elements, and (5) design of reaction processes possibly invoking metal carbene complexes generated from platinum or gold complexes and alkynes.

A review. Catalytic olefin metathesis-through which pairs of C:C bonds are reorganized-transforms simple mols. to those that are complex and precious. This class of reactions has noticeably enriched chem. synthesis, which is the art of prepg. scarce mols. with highly desirable properties (for example, medicinal agents or polymeric materials). Research in the past two decades has yielded structurally well-defined catalysts for olefin metathesis that are used to synthesize an array of mols. with unprecedented efficiency. Nonetheless, the full potential of olefin metathesis will be realized only when addnl. catalysts are discovered that are truly practical and afford exceptional selectivity for a significantly broader range of reactions.

A review. Catalytic olefin metathesis has quickly emerged as one of the most often-used transformations in modern chem. synthesis. One class of catalysts that has led the way to this significant development are the high-oxidn.-state alkylidene complexes of molybdenum. In this review key observations that resulted in the discovery and development of molybdenum- and tungsten-based metathesis catalysts are outlined. An account of the utility of molybdenum catalysts in the synthesis of biol. significant mols. is provided as well. Another focus of the review is the use of chiral molybdenum complexes for enantioselective synthesis. These highly efficient catalysts provide unique access to materials of exceptional enantiomeric purity and often without generating solvent waste. A review.

A review. Among the many types of transition metal-catalyzed C-C bond forming reactions, olefin metathesis has come to prominence in recent years owing to the wide range of transformations that are possible with com. available and easily handled catalysts. Olefin metathesis is now widely considered as one of the most powerful synthetic tools in org. chem. Better understanding of the mechanism and catalyst-substrate interactions has enabled researchers to use cross-metathesis reactions in multistep procedures and in the synthesis of natural products. In this review, various aspects of cross-metathesis reactions, such as ring-opening, intermol. enyne metathesis, applications in solid-phase synthesis, etc., were discussed by the authors.

A review. The advent of well-defined catalysts for olefin metathesis which combine high activity, durability, and excellent tolerance towards polar functional groups has revolutionized the field. The past decade has seen the rapid embrace of these reagents as tools for advanced org. and polymer chem. and the success of this development is witnessed by a plethora of elegant applications to the synthesis of natural and nonnatural products. This review article, with >200 refs., provides an overview of these developments and familiarizes the reader with some very recent advances which hold the promise to expand the scope of the reaction even further. Moreover, the pos. impact of metathesis on the fundamental logic of retrosynthetic planning is shown by means of typical examples. Finally, metathesis is by no means restricted to alkene substrates, and some comments on metathesis reactions following unconventional mechanistic pathways are also presented.

A review. In the past decade, numerous examples of chem. technologies based on olefin metathesis have been developed to make olefin metathesis increasingly dominant in several sustainable and green chem. processes. In spite of the wide application profile, conjugated olefin metathesis, esp. conjugated polyene metathesis, is an area of great interest with little exploration. The metathesis of conjugated polyenes is often cumbersome and requires a high catalyst loading, most probably because of the formation of poorly active or inactive ruthenium η3-vinylcarbene intermediates. A mechanistic understanding and the development of a new highly active catalytic system for olefin metathesis will open new areas for exploration, such as the utilization of cyclopentadiene and other petrochem. byproducts or a new way to use butadiene, isoprene and conjugated electron systems that contain natural products such as terpenes and polyunsatd. fatty acids. An understanding of the mechanism of ruthenium η1-η3-vinylcarbene interconversion may open the way to the development of a new generation of Ru-based latent metathesis catalyst systems. This review summarizes the most relevant pioneering work focused on the metathesis of conjugated polyenes to open new ideas for the development of forthcoming latent metathesis catalysts and to explore different applications.

A review. Acyclic diene metathesis (ADMET) polymn. is a powerful and versatile technique for creating precision polymers. Specialized and well-defined materials, as well as improved understanding of structure-property relationships, can be achieved by ADMET polymn. of designed sym. monomer structures. The introduction of functional groups into ADMET polymers, from polar groups to biodegradable moieties, has resulted in an array of precision functional materials with distinct properties and interesting applications.

A review. Olefin metathesis has been embraced by polymer chemists as a method for creating well-defined polymers. In particular, ADMET and ROMP have emerged as the primary modes of metathesis polymn. ADMET reactions are now common, found in textbooks, and easy to perform if the proper techniques are chosen. Much remains to be done, however, with work now focusing on silicon chem., direct control of tacticity in precision polymers, biol. applications, modeling crystal lattices in common polyolefins, exploring solid-state metathesis reactions, and creating water-sol. ADMET polymers.

A review. This article covers case studies in natural product syntheses with comments on various aspects of metathesis reactions and on how the difficulties encountered in these syntheses have led to better understanding of these reactions or to more effective reaction conditions and catalysts. Ring-closing metathesis leading to small and medium-sized rings is discussed, followed by macrocycle formation, asym. ring-closing metathesis, and cross metathesis.

A review. With the exception of palladium-catalyzed cross-couplings, no other group of reactions has had such a profound impact on the formation of carbon-carbon bonds and the art of total synthesis in the last quarter of a century than the metathesis reactions of olefins, enynes, and alkynes. Herein, we highlight a no. of selected examples of total syntheses in which such processes played a crucial role and which imparted to these endeavors certain elements of novelty, elegance, and efficiency. Judging from their short but impressive history, the influence of these reactions in chem. synthesis is destined to increase.

A review. The desire to utilize biobased feedstocks and develop more sustainable chem. poses new challenges in catalysis. A synthetically useful catalytic conversion is ethenolysis, a cross metathesis reaction with ethylene. In this Review, the state of the art of ethenolysis in biobased chem. was extensively examd. using Me oleate as a model compd. for fatty acids. Allied to this, the ethenolysis of fatty acid, polymers and more challenging substrates are reviewed. To det. the limiting factors for the application of ethenolysis on biomass, the influence of reaction parameters were investigated and the bottlenecks for reaching high turnover nos. identified.

Rapeseed oilmethyl ester (RME) and (bio)ethylene are converted into biofuel with an evenly rising b.p. curve, which fulfills the strict boiling specifications prescribed by the fuel std. EN 590 for modern (petro)diesel engines. Catalyzed by a Pd/Ru system, RME undergoes isomerizing metathesis in a stream of ethylene gas, leading to a defined olefin, monoester, and diester blend. This innovative refining concept requires negligible energy input (60°C) and no solvents and does not produce waste. It demonstrates that the pressing challenge of increasing the fraction of renewables in engine fuel may be addressed purely chem. rather than by motor engineering.

A review. Remarkable innovations have been made in the field of olefin metathesis due to the design and prepn. of new catalysts. Ethenolysis, which is cross-metathesis with ethylene, represents one catalytic transformation that has been used with the purpose of cleaving internal carbon-carbon double bonds. The objectives were either the ring opening of cyclic olefins to produce dienes or the shortening of unsatd. hydrocarbon chains to degrade polymers or generate valuable shorter terminal olefins in a controlled manner. This review summarizes several aspects of this reaction: the catalysts, their degrdn. in the presence of ethylene, some parameters driving their productivity, the side reactions, and the applications of ethenolysis in org. synthesis and in potential industrial applications.

Me 9-decenoate, but the implementation of this process has been hampered by low ethenolysis efficiencies. The conversion of seed oil based feedstocks such as Me oleate into useful com. raw materials via olefin metathesis was a research focus for decades, due to their low cost and renewable supply, but tech. success was limited due to poor catalyst activities and turnovers. The authors report here recent studies on the cross-metathesis of Me oleate with ethylene (ethenolysis) catalyzed by bis(tricyclohexylphosphine)benzylideneruthenium dichloride (1). At 25°/60 psig of ethylene, catalysis by 1 results in the highly selective formation of 1-decene and Me 9-decenoate. However, reactivity losses limit the catalyst turnovers well below com. viability in batch reactor operation. In an attempt to address the limitations of this chem., a combination of an exptl. evaluation of the impact of process parameters, a detailed anal. of the fundamental reaction steps, kinetic modeling, and mol. modeling was applied to develop a more detailed understanding of this complex catalytic pathway. These fundamental studies led to a more complete understanding of the factors impacting catalyst performance and the identification of approaches necessary to achieve an economically viable process.

A review. The catalytic routes for converting unsatd. fatty acid esters and related compds., obtained from renewable resources, into useful chem. products via the olefin metathesis reaction are discussed. These routes offer new possibilities for the oleochem. industry to contribute to a sustainable chem. industry. Highly selective homogeneous and heterogeneous catalyst systems developed for metathetical conversions are described. Supported rhenium oxide catalysts active at room temp., can be easily sepd. from the reaction mixt., and can be regenerated many times. New well-defined homogeneous ruthenium complexes are effective catalysts, showing high turnover nos. The present knowledge about the catalyst systems and the possibilities for practical applications for the metathetical conversion of unsatd. fatty acid esters and oils are discussed.

Jeon, Jong Yeol; Han, Yohan; Kim, Young-Wun; Lee, Youn-Woo; Hong, Sukwon; Hwang, In Taek

Bio-oil contains plant, animal, fish, and micro-algae oil, and more than 200 million tons are produced annually. However, many edible and non-edible bio-oils are still under development, and their value and feasibility have yet to be detd. The vast majority of bio-oils produced in the world have a very high unsatd. fatty acid content (70-98%), which could be used as a renewable, eco-friendly alternative to petroleum. Hydrolysis (or transesterification) with ethylene metathesis technol. converts unsatd. fatty acids to C4-C30 oil fragments. These oil fragments are a sustainable chem. technol. used in chem. industry platform technol. and carbon dioxide abatement green chem. technol., and as a petrochem. substitute. These platform chems. also have their own market but are used as raw materials for other products (polymers, surfactants, synthetic lubricants, plasticizers, other specialty chems., general purpose chems., biofuels, etc.). The biodegradability and biocompatibility of the polymeric materials made from the oil mean that it is also possible to develop diverse functional products with high added value such as toothpaste, dandruff treatment shampoo, and melanin pigment removal cosmetics, medical and shape memory polymer materials. According to the cradle-to-gate anal. for environmental impact and economics, the total carbon dioxide emission redn. per ton of soybean oil was estd. to be 1.5 kg kg-1 products. Moreover, the metathesis of soybean oil ($680/ton) with addnl. raw materials ($237.4) will generate a value that is 7.5 times higher at $6857. Due to the biodegradability and biocompatibility of the products made from bio-oils, it is expected that various functional products with high added value will be developed and that industrial applicability will be greatly expanded in the near future. In addn., for the development of various derivs., fusion and cooperative research in chem. fields such as catalytic engineering, org. chem., polymer chem., maintenance chem., and reaction engineering are essential. © 2019 Society of Chem. Industry and John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.

A review. Oils and fats of vegetable and animal origin have been the most important renewable feedstock of the chem. industry in the past and in the present. A tremendous geog. and feedstock shift of oleochem. prodn. has taken place from North America and Europe to southeast Asia. It will be important to introduce and to cultivate more and new oil plants contg. fatty acids with interesting and desired properties for chem. utilization while simultaneously increasing the agricultural biodiversity. The problem of the industrial utilization of food plant oils has become more urgent with the development of the global biodiesel prodn. The remarkable advances made during the last decade in org. synthesis, catalysis, and biotechnol. using plant oils and the basic oleochems. derived from them will be reported.

A review. A rapidly expanding area of inquiry is the use of plant biomass for the industrial prodn. of org. compds. for which there is high demand. This interest is fuelled largely by the anticipated decline in the supply of petroleum, and the inevitable concomitant rise in cost. Over the past 30 years, significant progress has been made toward the large-scale conversion of plant biomass to common chems. However, examn. of the list of top prodn. org. chems. reveals numerous opportunities for future development. Progress toward efficient and economical prodn. of these challenging targets from biomass has recently been reported, and future success is likely to continue through academic and industrial collaboration.

A review. Vegetable fats such as rapeseed oil, sunflower oil, palm oil or coconut oil consisting of triglycerides offer different carbon chain distributions. The use of these raw materials for the prodn. of industrial chems. as well as for fuel (biodiesel), which is finally a substitution for mineral oil, is a political discussion with various facets. The basic products such as fatty acids, fatty alcs., and esters have different phys. properties and lead to various areas of application depending on the carbon chain distribution. While the chain length range of C12 represents important raw materials for detergents, chain lengths of C18 are used mainly in industrial applications, e.g. as lubricants. Natural fatty alcs. are produced by the heterogeneous catalyzed high-pressure hydrogenation of Me esters or fatty acids. The unsatd. fats and oils can be derivatized catalytically by functionalization, oligomerization, oxidn. or metathesis. Thereby, new functional groups are introduced into the oleochem. substrate. The carbon chain length can be increased or reduced resp., or a branching in the fatty chain is introduced. Products with completely new properties and areas of applications are available due to these catalytic variations of fats and oils.

A review. Ruthenium-catalyzed olefin metathesis reactions represent an attractive and powerful transformation for the formation of new carbon-carbon double bonds. This area is now quite familiar to most chemists as numerous catalysts are available that enable a plethora of olefin metathesis reactions. Nevertheless, with the exception of uses in polymn. reactions, only a limited no. of industrial processes use olefin metathesis. This is mainly due to difficulties assocd. with removing ruthenium from the final products. In this context, a no. of studies have been carried out to develop procedures for the removal of the catalyst or the products of catalyst decompn., however, none are universally attractive so far. This situation has resulted in tremendous activity in the area dealing with supported or tagged versions of homogeneous catalysts. This Review summarizes the numerous studies focused on developing cleaner ruthenium-catalyzed metathesis processes.

A review. The metathesis of natural oils and fats and their derivs. is a clean catalytic reaction that can be considered as an example of green chem. Using this reaction, oleochem. feedstocks can be converted into valuable chem. products, directly or in only a few reaction steps. With the development of catalysts that are active and highly selective under mild reaction conditions, there are favorable perspectives for the application of the metathesis reaction in the oleochem. industry.

A review. The last 20 years have brought a series of breakthroughs in polyolefins catalysis technol. From Ziegler-Natta catalysis technol., to metallocene technol. in the 1990s, to post-metallocene technol. today, each new development has increased the producer's freedom in more precisely controlling polymer structure and properties. In the early 1990s, metallocene technol. allowed control of polymer compn. distributions and long chain branching. Today, post-metallocene technol. allows control of stereo-/regio-defects on the polymer backbone for unique propylene-based elastomers and allows control of comonomer blockiness' for olefin block copolymers. Better control of polymer structure enables a mol. architecture approach in product design to rapidly capture market development needs. This article overviews these technol. breakthroughs and describes ongoing research at The Dow Chem. Company in developing new olefins products based on metallocene and post-metallocene technologies. While Dow is highlighted (as the authors are most familiar with the work at Dow), there has been tremendous progress and activity from Exxon Chem. Company and more recently Mitsui Petrochem. and Nova Corporation along with others.

Examd. herein is the basis for the outstanding metathesis productivity of leading cyclic alkyl amino carbene (CAAC) catalysts relative to their important N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) predecessors, as recently demonstrated in the topical contexts of metathesis macrocyclization and the ethenolysis of renewable oils. The difference is traced to the stability to decompn. of the metallacyclobutane (MCB) intermediate. The CAAC catalysts are shown to undergo little to no β-H elimination of the MCB ring, a pathway to which the H2IMes catalysts are highly susceptible. Unexpectedly, however, the CAAC catalysts are found to be more susceptible to bimol. coupling of the key intermediate RuCl2(CAAC)(:CH2), a reaction that culminates in elimination of the methylidene ligand as ethylene. Thus, an NMR study of transiently stabilized RuCl2(L)(py)(:CH2) complexes (L = CAAC or H2IMes) revealed bimol. decompn. of the CAAC deriv. within 5 min at RT, as compared to a time scale of hours for the H2IMes analog. The remarkable productivity of the CAAC catalysts is thus due to their resistance to β-elimination, which enables their use at part per million loadings, and to the retarding effect of these low catalyst concns. on bimol. decompn.

The correlation between rapid initiation and rapid decompn. in olefin metathesis is probed for a series of fast-initiating, phosphine-free Ru catalysts: the Hoveyda catalyst HII, RuCl2(L)(:CHC6H4-o-OiPr); the Grela catalyst nG (a deriv. of HII with a nitro group para to OiPr); the Piers catalyst PII, [RuCl2(L)(:CHPCy3)]OTf; the third-generation Grubbs catalyst GIII, RuCl2(L)(py)2(:CHPh); and dianiline catalyst DA, RuCl2(L)(o-dianiline)(:CHPh), in all of which L = H2IMes = N,N'-bis(mesityl)imidazolin-2-ylidene. Prior studies of ethylene metathesis have established that various Ru metathesis catalysts can decomp. by β-elimination of propene from the metallacyclobutane intermediate RuCl2(H2IMes)(κ2-C3H6), Ru-2. The present work demonstrates that in metathesis of terminal olefins, β-elimination yields only ca. 25-40% propenes for HII, nG, PII, or DA, and none for GIII. The discrepancy is attributed to competing decompn. via bimol. coupling of methylidene intermediate RuCl2(H2IMes)(:CH2), Ru-1. Direct evidence for methylidene coupling is presented, via the controlled decompn. of transiently stabilized adducts of Ru-1, RuCl2(H2IMes)Ln(:CH2) (Ln = pyn'; n' = 1, 2, or o-dianiline). These adducts were synthesized by treating in situ-generated metallacyclobutane Ru-2 with pyridine or o-dianiline, and were isolated by pptg. at low temp. (-116 or -78 °C, resp.). On warming, both undergo methylidene coupling, liberating ethylene and forming RuCl2(H2IMes)Ln. A mechanism is proposed based on kinetic studies and mol.-level computational anal. Bimol. coupling emerges as an important contributor to the instability of Ru-1, and a potentially major pathway for decompn. of fast-initiating, phosphine-free metathesis catalysts.

McClennan, William L.; Rufh, Stephanie A.; Lummiss, Justin A. M.; Fogg, Deryn E.

Sterically accessible Lewis donors are shown to accelerate decompn. during catalysis, for a broad range of Grubbs-class metathesis catalysts. These include benzylidene derivs. RuCl2(NHC)(PCy3)(=CHPh) (Ru-2: NHC = H2IMes, a; IMes, b; H2IPr, c; IPr, d; H2ITol, e) and indenylidene complexes RuCl2(NHC)(PCy3)(=C15H10) (NHC = H2IMes, Ru-2f; IMes, Ru-2g). All of these precatalysts form methylidene complex RuCl2(NHC)(=CH2) Ru-3 as the active species in metathesis of terminal olefins, and generate RuCl2(NHC)(PCy3)(=CH2) Ru-4 as the catalyst resting state. On treatment with a 10-fold excess of pyridine, Ru-4a and Ru-4b decompd. within minutes in soln. at RT, eliminating [MePCy3]Cl A by net loss of three ligands (PCy3, methylidene, and one chloride), and a mesityl proton. In comparison, loss of A from Ru-4a in the absence of a donor requires up to 3 days at 55 °C. The σ-alkyl intermediate RuCl2(13CH2PCy3)(NHC)(py)2 resulting from nucleophilic attack of free PCy3 on the methylidene ligand was undetectable for the H2IMes system, but was spectroscopically observable for the IMes system. The relevance of this pathway to decompn. of catalysts Ru-2a-g was demonstrated by assessing the impact of pyridine on the in situ-generated methylidene species. Slow initiation (as obsd. for the indenylidene catalysts) did not protect against methylidene abstraction. Importantly, studies with Ru-4a and Ru-4b indicated that weaker donors (THF, MeCN, DMSO, MeOH, and even H2O) likewise promote this pathway, at rates that increase with donor concn., and severely degrade catalyst productivity in RCM, even for a readily cyclized substrate. In all cases, A was the sole or major 31P-contg. decompn. product. For DMSO, a first-order dependence of decompn. rates on DMSO concn. was established. This behavior sends a warning about the use of phosphine-stabilized metathesis catalysts in donor solvents, or with substrates bearing readily accessible donor sites. Addn. of pyridine to RuCl2(H2IMes)(PCy3)(=CHMe) did not result in ethylidene abstraction, indicating that this decompn. pathway can be inhibited by use of substrates in which the olefin bears a β-Me group.

Reactions are described of the second-generation Hoveyda catalyst HII with amines, pyridine, and DBU (1,8-diazabicyclo[5.4.0]undec-7-ene), in the presence and absence of olefin substrates. These nitrogen bases have a profoundly neg. impact on metathesis yields, but in most cases, they are innocuous toward the precatalyst. HII adducts were formed by primary and secondary amines (n-butylamine, sec-butylamine, benzylamine, pyrrolidine, morpholine), pyridine, and DBU at room temp. No reaction was evident for NEt3, even at 60 °C. On longer reaction at RT, unencumbered primary amines abstr. the benzylidene ligand from HII. With 10 equiv of NH2nBu, this process was complete in 12 h, affording NHnBu(CH2Ar) (Ar = o-C6H4-OiPr) and [RuCl(H2IMes)(NH2nBu)4]Cl. For benzylamine, benzylidene abstraction occurred over days at RT. No such reaction was obsd. for sec-butylamine, secondary amines, NEt3, pyridine, or DBU. All of these bases, however, strongly inhibited metathesis of styrene by HII, with a general trend toward more deleterious effects with higher Bronsted basicity. Studies at 10 mol % of HII and 10 equiv of DBU, NEt3, and pyrrolidine (60 °C, C6D6) indicated that the primary mechanism for decompn. involved base-induced deprotonation of the metallacyclobutane intermediate, rather than the Lewis base-mediated decompn. pathways previously established for the Grubbs catalysts. In the corresponding metathesis of ethylene, this decompn. process is rapid even at RT, highlighting the vulnerability of the less substituted metallacyclobutane.

Amine-mediated decompn. during olefin metathesis reactions that employ the second-generation Grubbs catalyst is studied. For most amines, the dominant deactivation pathway involves ejection of the PCy3 (Cy = cyclohexyl) ligand by the amine, followed by abstraction of the methylidene moiety from the resting-state species RuCl2(H2IMes)(PCy3)(=CH2) (H2IMes = 1,3-dimesityl-4,5-dihydroimidazol-2-ylidene) as [MePCy3]Cl. An exception is highly basic 1,8-diazabicyclo[5.4.0]undec-7-ene (DBU), which is slow to degrade the resting-state methylidene complex, and for which the phosphonium byproduct is not obsd. However, DBU is shown to rapidly attack a species generated during catalysis, most probably the metallacyclobutane intermediate.

Routes are described to previously unreported first- and second-generation Grubbs metathesis catalysts bearing a 13C label at the key benzylidene or methylidene site. Improved syntheses of the 2H-labeled isotopologues are also presented. Labeling at the alkylidene position is important because it provides unique, direct information about changes at the active site of the catalyst, and the fate of the [Ru]=CHR ligand during catalyst deactivation. A case study demonstrates the power of 13C-labeling in tracking the methylidene moiety in amine-induced decompn. of the second-generation complex RuCl2(PCy3)(H2IMes)(=13CH2). Also reported is the soly. of ethylene in C6D6 and CD2Cl2, measured at 296 ± 1.5 K and 101.0 ± 0.8 kPa.

Reaction kinetics and mechanistic studies for ethylene-internal alkyne metathesis promoted by the phosphine-free initiator Ru1 (Piers's catalyst) is described. The kinetic order of reactants and catalyst was detd. The effect of ethylene was studied at different soln. concns. using ethylene gas mixts. applied at const. pressure. Unlike earlier studies with the second-generation Grubbs complex, ethylene was found to show an inverse first-order rate dependence. Under catalytic conditions, a ruthenacyclobutane intermediate was obsd. by proton NMR spectroscopy at low temp. Combined with the kinetic study, these data suggest a catalytic cycle involving a reactive LnRu=CH2 species in equil. with ethylene to form a ruthenacyclobutane, a catalyst resting state. Rates were detd. for a variety of internal alkynes of varying substitution. Also, at low ethylene pressures, preparative syntheses of several 2,3-disubstituted 1,3-butadienes were achieved. Using the kinetic method, several phosphine-free inhibitors were examd. for their ability to promote ethylene-alkyne metathesis and to guide selection of the optimal catalyst.

The decompn. of a series of ruthenium metathesis catalysts was examd. using phosphine and imidazolidinylidene methylene species [(L1)(L2)X2Ru:CH2] (L1, L2 = PCy3, 1,3-Ar2C3H4N2-κC2; Ar = mesityl, 2,6-iPrC6H3) as model complexes. All of the phosphine-contg. methylene complexes decompd. to generate methylphosphonium salts, and their decompn. routes followed first-order kinetics. The formation of these salts in high conversion, coupled with the obsd. kinetic behavior for this reaction, suggests that the major decompn. pathway involves nucleophilic attack of a dissocd. phosphine on the methylene carbon. This mechanism also is consistent with decompn. obsd. in the presence of ethylene as a model olefin substrate. The decompn. of phosphine-free catalyst (H2IMes)(Cl)2Ru:CH(2-C6H4-O-i-Pr) (H2IMes = 1,3-dimesityl-imidazolidin-2-ylidene) with ethylene was found to generate unidentified ruthenium hydride species. Ruthenacyclobutane decomposition, involving competitive beta-hydride transfer to Ru and reductive olefin elimination during ruthenium-catalyzed olefin metathesis, is predicted by density functional theory calculations and experimentally confirmed by propene and butene formation during degenerate Ru-methylidene-catalyzed metathesis of ethylene. The results provide new focus on the nature of ruthenium metathesis catalyst decomposition under catalytic conditions.

Ru-based metathesis catalysts employed in cyclopolymn. (CP) of 1,6-heptadiyne derivs. have promoted regioselective α-addn. to alkynes, forming various conjugated polyenes contg. exclusively five-membered repeat units. Recently, we discovered that a new chelated Ru catalyst could promote regioselective β-addn. to produce analogous polyenes contg. six-membered rings with moderate to good β-selectivity. Since then, we have focused our research on pursuing more active and β-selective regiocontrol to produce conjugated polymers with excellent β-selectivity, with a much broader range of monomers. Herein, we demonstrate highly β-selective CP by combining a new dithiolate-chelated Ru-based catalyst with weakly coordinating pyridine additives, which significantly enhance the conversion and β-selectivity. An in-depth mechanistic investigation by 1H NMR revealed a prominent role for the additives, which improve the stability of the propagating carbene.

Phosphine-stabilized metathesis catalysts are among the most popular and widely used catalysts in org. synthesis. The second-generation Grubbs catalyst GII, in particular, dominates synthetic applications of olefin metathesis. This is commonly true even for reactions that are fundamentally incompatible with free PCy3, which is released upon entry of GII into the catalytic cycle. A leading example is cross-metathesis with electron-deficient olefins such as acrylates, for which yields are seriously degraded by a deleterious side reaction involving attack of free PCy3 on the acrylate olefin, and prodn. of an enolate anion that decomps. the active catalyst. Here we describe a simple, powerful means of upgrading the performance of GII and its indenylidene analog M2 to levels matching or exceeding that of the important, but more costly, phosphine-free Hoveyda catalyst HII. Key to this improvement is carrying out the reaction in the presence of a phenol-functionalized polymer resin. We demonstrate that, at std. catalyst loadings (which correspond to low concns. of PCy3), the beneficial effect of phenol arises not from protonation of PCy3 itself, but from protonation of the enolate, thereby converting this aggressive base into an innocuous phosphonium salt. The methodol. is showcased in the demanding cross-metathesis of the renewable phenylpropanoid trans-anethole with 2-ethylhexyl acrylate (an efficient route to the high-value antioxidant octylmethoxycinnamate, an active ingredient in sunscreen formulations with the tradename Octinoxate), as well as Me acrylate, a ubiquitous and more sterically accessible coupling partner. Expts. with water-satd. toluene indicate that water cannot be substituted for the resin as a sacrificial proton donor, such treatment resulting in drastically reduced productivity. Control expts. involving macrocyclization indicate that the resin has an addnl. protective function beyond enolate quenching, potentially due to hydrogen bonding of polar contaminants present as impurities in the reagents or reaction medium.

Cyclopolymn. (CP) of 1,6-heptadiynes using olefin metathesis catalysts is a useful method for producing various conjugated polyenes. Unfortunately, com. available user-friendly Grubbs catalysts have long been known to be inactive toward CP. However, recent mechanistic studies revealed that the problem did not lie with the intrinsic activities of Grubbs catalysts but the stability of the propagating carbenes, as decompd. carbene species catalyzed a [2 + 2 + 2] cycloaddn. side reaction instead of CP. Fortunately, by adding weakly coordinating ligands such as pyridines as stabilizers, a highly active and fast-initiating third-generation Grubbs catalyst could successfully promote living CP. However, there was no report of CP using the much cheaper but less active first-generation Grubbs catalyst (G1), which has been widely used for more than 20 years. Believing that G1 should also be able to catalyze CP, we came up with three strategies to enhance the activity of G1 toward CP. By categorizing numerous additives into three distinct classes and conducting extensive reaction screening, we discovered two new excellent additives to G1: benzoic acid and sodium benzoate, both of which successfully produced various trans-selective conjugated polyenes with mol. wts. of up to 23 kDa. Interestingly, additives optimal for CP catalyzed by G1 were not suitable for CP catalyzed by Grubbs catalysts contg. N-heterocyclic carbene ligands and vice versa, thus implying that their activation mechanisms were distinctly different. Therefore, we conducted kinetic studies and mechanistic investigation by 1H and 31P NMR spectroscopy to reveal that these two additives, despite having very similar chem. structures, enhance the CP efficiency via very different mechanisms; benzoic acid accelerated phosphine dissocn. and stabilized the propagating carbene, while sodium benzoate mediated the exchange of an anionic ligand to afford a more active catalyst. Addnl., these additives also suppressed or retarded the [2 + 2 + 2] cycloaddn. side reaction to further enhance the efficiency and selectivity of CP. In brief, this study revealed new insights into the use of Grubbs catalysts to facilitate CP two decades after their invention, and this should greatly broaden the utility of CP because G1 is the cheapest and the most readily available olefin metathesis catalyst.

Cyclopolymn. (CP) of 1,6-heptadiyne derivs. using the Grubbs catalysts has been known to afford conjugated polyenes in low yields in dichloromethane (DCM), the most common solvent for olefin metathesis polymn. and a good solvent for typical conjugated polymers. Based on our previous work that showed highly efficient CP using the Grubbs catalysts in THF (THF), we developed a new polymn. system using weakly coordinating additives with the third-generation Grubbs catalyst in DCM. The polymn. efficiency of various monomers and their controls dramatically increased by adding 3,5-dichloropyridine, yielding polymers with narrow polydispersity indexes (PDIs) at low temps. These new reaction conditions not only expand the monomer scope by resolving the soly. concerns of conjugated polymers but also more effectively reduced the chain transfer. Consequently, fully conjugated diblock copolymer was successfully prepd. Addnl., kinetic anal. has revealed that low CP efficiency in DCM resulted from the rapid decompn. of the propagating carbene. This decompn. was effectively suppressed by both pyridine additives and THF, suggesting that weakly coordinating additives stabilize the living chain end. Furthermore, we obsd. that the turnover no. of CP was higher at lower temps. (0-10 °C) than at ambient temps., consistent with the understanding that the lifetime of a propagating carbene is greater at lower temps. Steric protection was also shown to increase the stability of the propagating carbene, as shown by a higher turnover no. for the 3,3-dimethyl-substituted 1,6-heptadiyne compared to the nonfunctionalized monomer.

Copper iodide has been shown to be an effective cocatalyst for the olefin cross-metathesis reaction. In particular, it has both a catalyst stabilizing effect due to iodide ion, as well as copper(I)-based phosphine-scavenging properties that apply to use of the Grubbs-2 catalyst. A variety of Michael acceptors and olefinic partners can be cross-coupled under mild conditions in refluxing di-Et ether that avoid chlorinated solvents. This effect has also been applied to chem. in water at room temp. using the new surfactant TPGS-750-M.

In olefin metathesis, ring-closing olefin metathesis, and cross-metathesis reactions catalyzed by ruthenium carbene complexes, the addn. of benzoquinones such as 1,4-benzoquinone to the reaction mixts. inhibits isomerization reactions of the products. Stereoselective isomerizations of (Z)-Me3CSi(Me)2OCH2CH2CH:CHCO2Me and (Z)-Me3CSi(Me)2OCH2CH:CHCH2OSi(Me)2CMe3 to their corresponding (E)-isomers yield 81% and >95% of silyl enol ether products derived from olefin isomerization in the absence of an additive, while isomerization in the presence of 1,4-benzoquinone yields >95% yields of the desired products. The ring closing metathesis reactions of N,N-diallylaniline and of diallyl ether in the presence of the 2nd generation Grubbs olefin metathesis catalyst provide >90% yields of the dihydropyrrole and dihydrofuran products in the presence of 1,4-benzoquinone, while yielding 16% and <5% yields of the desired products in the absence of an additive. Cross-metathesis reactions of meadow foam Me esters RCH:CH(CH2)3CO2Me [R = Me(CH2)13, Me(CH2)15, Me(CH2)7CH:CH(CH2)6] and of Me(CH2)5CH:CH(CH2)10OAc with ethylene in the presence of (benzylidene)bis(tricyclohexylphosphino)ruthenium dichloride provide Me 5-hexenoate and 1-decene and 11-dodecen-1-yl acetate with 1-2% isomerization in the presence of 1,4-benzoquinone, while providing products with 30-49% isomerization in the absence of an additive. Nine benzoquinones are tried as isomerization inhibitors for ruthenium-catalyzed olefin metathesis reactions; benzoquinones with electron-withdrawing substituents such as tetrafluoro-1,4-benzoquinone and 2,6-dichloro-1,4-benzoquinones are the most effective additives of those tried for inhibiting olefin isomerization reactions. 1,4-Benzoquinone is not effective at preventing isomerization reactions in the ring-closing metathesis of either N-Me diallylamine or N-benzyldiallylamine. Acetic acid is an effective additive for preventing olefin shifts in the isomerization of (Z)-Me3CSi(Me)2OCH2CH2CH:CHCO2Me and in the ring-closing metathesis of diallyl ether, but is ineffective at preventing undesired isomerization in the stereoisomerization of (Z)-Me3CSi(Me)2OCH2CH:CHCH2OSi(Me)2CMe3.

The performance of certain olefin metathesis reactions catalyzed by Grubbs catalysts was enhanced by the simple addn. of phenol. Addn. of phenol to self-metathesis reactions catalyzed by 1 produced very small quantities of unwanted byproducts and allowed for room-temp. metathesis at high substrate:catalyst loadings. The efficiency of cross-metathesis reactions between Me acrylate and 1-decene catalyzed by 2 was also significantly increased by addn. of p-cresol to the reaction mixt. Mechanistic studies, including NMR spectroscopy and DFT calcns., established that phenol is playing a no. of pos. roles in the active metathesis cycle, including altering the relative rates of phosphine loss and rebinding, activating the carbene C for reaction with olefinic substrate, and hemilabile stabilization of the key 14-electron intermediate species.

The efficient selective cross-metathesis (CM) of acrylonitrile using unmodified Grubbs precatalyst is reported. The use of copper(I) chloride as an additive and phosphane scavenger is described and significant turnover enhancement upon addn. of a metallic salt in selective CM is obsd. for the first time. The influence of catalyst decompn. and other exptl. parameters (concn., amt. of acrylonitrile used) on conversion is also demonstrated.

The N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ligands H2IAd (H2IAd = 1,3-di(1-adamantyl)-4,5-dihydroimidazol-2-ylidene) and H2IAdMes (H2IAdMes = 1-(1-adamantyl)-3-mesityl-4,5-dihydroimidazol-2-ylidine) were prepd. and treated with [RuCl2(:CHPh)(PCy3)2] (1). While H2IAd failed to react with 1, H2IAdMes readily produced [RuCl2(:CHPh)(H2IAdMes)(PCy3)] (7). Only a single isomer of 7 was formed, this being that with the mesityl ring situated above the benzylidene moiety, as confirmed by an x-ray structure. Complex 7 was only a very poor olefin metathesis catalyst, likely a consequence of the excessive steric crowding imparted by the 1-adamantyl moiety towards the position trans to the benzylidene group.

The previously reported Ru carbenes (PCy3)2Cl2Ru:CHR (R = CHCPh2 (1a), Ph (1b)) react with the bridged-chloride dimers [(p-cymene)RuCl2]2, [(p-cymene)OsCl2]2, and [(tBu2Cp)RhCl2]2 to quant. form the bimetallic, bridged-chloride Ru carbenes (p-cymene)(Cl)M(μ-Cl)2Ru(Cl)(PCy3)(CHR) (same R; M = Ru 2a,b, Os 4a,b, and Rh 6a,b) and 1 equiv of each corresponding piano-stool complex. In the ring-opening metathesis polymn. of 1,5-cyclooctadiene, catalyst activity increases in the order M = Ru < Os < Rh for the ancillary metal centers, with all of the bimetallic catalysts having higher activities than 1a,b. The kinetics of ROMP of endo,endo-4,5-bis(methoxymethyl)norbornene 9 were studied using catalyst 2a, and the data support an associative mechanism of olefin metathesis, contrary to the mechanism of olefin metathesis proposed for the parent catalysts 1a,b.

Several ruthenium-based olefin metathesis catalysts of the formula (PR3)2X2Ru:CHCHCPh2 have been synthesized, and relative catalyst activities were detd. by monitoring the ring-closing metathesis of the acyclic diene di-Et diallylmalonate. The following order of increasing activity was detd.: X = I < Br < Cl and PR3 = PPh3 « PiPr2Ph < PCy2Ph < PiPr3 < PCy3. Addnl. studies were conducted with the catalyst (PCy3)2Cl2Ru:CH2 to probe the mechanism of olefin metathesis by this class of catalysts. The data support a scheme in which there are two competing pathways: the dominant one in which a phosphine dissocs. from the ruthenium center and a minor one in which both phosphines remain bound. Higher catalyst activities could be achieved by the addn. of CuCl to the reaction.

A new family of 1,3-dimesityl-4,5-dihydroimidazol-2-ylidene-substituted ruthenium-based complexes has been prepd. starting from RuCl2(:CHPh)(PCy3)2. These air- and water-tolerant complexes were shown to exhibit an increased ring-closing metathesis activity at elevated temp. when compared to that of the parent complex and a previously developed complex. In many instances the activity of these complexes also rivaled or exceeded that of an alkoxy-imido molybdenum complex. Catalyst loadings of as low as 0.05 mol % could be used.

Several highly active, recoverable and recyclable Ru-based metathesis catalysts are presented. The crystal structure of the Ru complex (I) bearing a 1,3-dimesityl-4,5-dihydroimidazol-2-ylidene and styrenyl ether ligand is disclosed. The heterocyclic ligand significantly enhances the catalytic activity, and the styrenyl ether allows for the easy recovery of the Ru complex. Catalyst I promotes ring-closing metathesis (RCM) and the efficient formation of various trisubstituted olefins at ambient temp. in high yield within 2 h; the catalyst is obtained in >95% yield after silica gel chromatog. and can be used directly in subsequent reactions. Tetrasubstituted olefins can also be synthesized by RCM reactions catalyzed by I. In addn., the synthesis and catalytic activities of two dendritic and recyclable Ru-based complexes are disclosed. Examples involving catalytic ring-closing, ring-opening, and cross metatheses are presented where, unlike monomer I, the dendritic catalyst can be readily recovered.

The relative TONs of productive and nonproductive metathesis reactions of di-Et diallylmalonate are compared for eight different ruthenium-based catalysts. Nonproductive cross metathesis is proposed to involve a chain-carrying ruthenium methylidene. A second more challenging substrate (di-Me allylmethylallylmalonate) that forms a trisubstituted olefin product is used to further delineate the effect of catalyst structure on the relative efficiencies of these processes. A steric model is proposed to explain the obsd. trends.

In our search for more-selective olefin metathesis catalysts, a series of Hoveyda-Grubbs-type second-generation complexes bearing unsym. N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ligands were synthesized and tested in model reactions. It was found that the N-benzyl substituent in NHC has a pos. influence on the selectivity of the newly obtained catalysts in the self-metathesis reaction of α-olefins. As expected, a typical relationship between activity and selectivity with respect to the N-aryl substituent used was obsd. Dipp-contg. complexes exhibited higher stability at elevated temp., while Mes-bearing complexes typically gave better yields than their Dipp analogs.

The search for a low-cost process for the valorization of linear α-olefins combining high productivity and high selectivity is a longstanding goal for chemists. Herein, we report a sol. ruthenium olefin metathesis catalyst that performs the conversion of linear α-olefins to longer internal linear olefins with high selectivity (>99%) under neat conditions at low loadings (50 ppm) and without the need of expensive additives. This robust catalytic process allowed us to efficiently and selectively re-equilibrate the naphtha fraction (C5-C8) of a Fischer-Tropsch feed derived from non-petroleum resources to a higher-value product range (C9-C14), useful as detergent and plasticizer precursors.

A review of the catalytic olefin metathesis for C-C bond formation in org. and polymer chem. and the Grubbs' 1st generation catalyst 1 as a highly efficient metathesis catalyst tolerating a wide variety of functional groups. The introduction of N-heterocyclic carbenes (NHCs) as ligands has afforded the more stable and active 2nd generation Ru catalyst 2. Several Ru metathesis initiators of the 2nd generation type were prepd. from various NHCs. Altering the steric and electronic properties of the ligand can control the activity and selectivity of the NHC coordinated catalysts. One of the reported modifications for the NHC-contg. Ru metathesis initiators is the application of unsym. NHC ligands. The unsym. nature of these ligands may lead to the selective catalysts in different metathesis reactions. This survey highlights the developments in Ru catalysts coordinated with unsym. NHC ligands and their trends in activity and selectivity on olefin metathesis. The discussion includes the description of Ru initiators coordinated with N-aryl-N'-alkyl NHCs, N-aryl-N'-aryl NHCs, and those coordinated with two unsym. NHCs. Ru complexes bearing chiral NHCs, cyclic (alkyl) (amino) carbenes (CAACs) as well as thiazol-2-ylidene ligands are also described.

New robust and air-stable ruthenium(II) indenylidene second-generation precatalysts with unsym. N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ligands were synthesized. These complexes were studied using ring-closing metathesis (RCM) of di-Et diallylmalonate (5; DEDAM) as a model substrate. Two new complexes contg. OMe and NMe2 groups in the NHC ligand, namely [1-(2,4,6-trimethylphenyl)-3-(2-methoxybenzyl)-2-imidazolidinylidene]dichloro(3-phenyl-1H-inden-1-ylidene)(tricyclohexylphosphine)ruthenium(II) (4a) and [1-(2,4,6-trimethylphenyl)-3-(2-N,N-dimethylaminobenzyl)-2-imidazolidinylidene]dichloro(3-phenyl-1H-inden-1-ylidene)(tricyclohexylphosphine)ruthenium(II) (4b), show increased activity in comparison to the parent [1,3-bis(2,4,6-trimethylphenyl)-2-imidazolidinylidene]dichloro(3-phenyl-1H-inden-1-ylidene)(tricyclohexylphosphine)ruthenium(II) (Umicore M2). Interestingly, the complex [1-(2,4,6-trimethylphenyl)-3-(2-thiomethylbenzyl)-2-imidazolidinylidene]dichloro(3-phenyl-1H-inden-1-ylidene)(tricyclohexylphosphine)ruthenium(II) (4c), bearing a SMe substituent, showed very low activity in the model RCM reaction with di-Et diallylmalonate (5). Application of the active complexes for metathesis reactions with a broad spectrum of olefins in com.-grade solvents in air was examd.

A new family of ruthenium-based olefin metathesis catalysts bearing a series of thiazole-2-ylidene ligands has been prepd. These complexes are readily accessible in one step from com. available (PCy3)2Cl2Ru:CHPh or (PCy3)Cl2Ru:CH(o-iPrO-Ph) and have been fully characterized. The X-ray crystal structures of four of these complexes are disclosed. In the solid state, the aryl substituents of the thiazole-2-ylidene ligands are located above the empty coordination site of the ruthenium center. Despite the decreased steric bulk of their ligands, all of the complexes reported herein efficiently promote benchmark olefin metathesis reactions such as the ring-closing of diethyldiallyl and diethylallylmethallyl malonate and the ring-opening metathesis polymn. of 1,5-cyclooctadiene and norbornene, as well as the cross metathesis of allyl benzene with cis-1,4-diacetoxy-2-butene and the macrocyclic ring-closing of a 14-membered lactone. The phosphine-free catalysts of this family are more stable than their phosphine-contg. counterparts, exhibiting pseudo-first-order kinetics in the ring-closing of diethyldiallyl malonate. Upon removing the steric bulk from the ortho positions of the N-aryl group of the thiazole-2-ylidene ligands, the phosphine-free catalysts lose stability, but when the substituents become too bulky the resulting catalysts show prolonged induction periods. Among five thiazole-2-ylidene ligands examd., 3-(2,4,6-trimethylphenyl)- and 3-(2,6-diethylphenyl)-4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-ylidene afforded the most efficient and stable catalysts. In the cross metathesis reaction of allyl benzene with cis-1,4-diacetoxy-2-butene increasing the steric bulk at the ortho positions of the N-aryl substituents results in catalysts that are more Z-selective.

The facile synthesis of two new unsym. N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ligands from com. available monosubstituted diamines, RNHCH2CH2NH2 (R = Me, Et), is presented. The resultant unsym. NHC ligands were complexed to Ru to give novel olefin metathesis initiators. Of particular interest, the new complexes (7a, shown as I; R = mesityl, R1 = cyclohexyl; 8a, shown as II; R = mesityl) gave significantly different E:Z ratios in cross-metathesis reactions and gave an improved selectivity in diastereoselective ring-closing metathesis, in comparison to the corresponding Grubbs 2 and Hoveyda-Grubbs complexes. The structures of 8a and its ethylated counterpart were detd. by x-ray crystallog.

Second-generation ruthenium olefin metathesis catalysts were investigated with systematic variation of the unsym. uNHC ligands. Depending on the uNHC steric bulk, the catalysts exhibited different activity and selectivity in metathesis reactions. DFT calcns. and X-ray crystallog. data were used to understand the influence of uNHC ligand structure on the catalyst properties. Furthermore, the catalysts were examd. in the context of reactions that are problematic for general-purpose Ru catalysts, including industrially important self-cross metathesis of α-olefins and ethenolysis of Et oleate.

A wide set of 65 diverse Ru metathesis catalysts was investigated in the ethenolysis reaction of bio-sourced Et oleate to allow the comparison between the catalyst structure and its activity and selectivity. Handling of the oleic substrate, weighting of the catalysts and charging the reactor was done in air, with exclusion of a glovebox or Schlenk techniques use. A catalyst bearing the unsym. N-heterocyclic ligand featuring a thiophene fragment (Ru-63) was selected to offer the best combination between high selectivity and sufficient activity under conditions mimicking oil industry-practice. A proof-of-concept large scale ethenolysis expt. was done with the selected catalyst to prove its high selectivity also at 1 L scale reaction with 90% pure non-distd. substrate.

Hoveyda-Grubbs 2nd-generation catalysts contg. N-alkyl/N'-aryl N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ligands were synthesized and studied in representative olefin metathesis reactions. Steric perturbations of unsym. NHCs were achieved through modulation of the hindrance of alkyl (neopentyl, neophyl, cyclohexyl) and aryl (2-isopropylphenyl, mesityl) substituents at the N atoms in combination with different backbone configurations (syn and anti). The NHC substitution patterns strongly influence the stability and reactivity of the corresponding complexes. In general, complexes bearing an anti NHC backbone are more stable and more active than their corresponding syn isomers. In both the series, the presence of bulky, highly branched N-alkyl groups tends to give reduced catalytic differences between syn and anti isomers, whereas the nature of the N'-aryl substituent (2-isopropylphenyl or mesityl) gives rise to different activity and/or selectivity. Of note, an N'-mesityl catalyst with anti backbone is highly competent in the ethenolysis of Et oleate, achieving up to 90% selectivity for the formation of terminal olefins.

A library of 29 homologous Ru-based olefin metathesis catalysts was tested for ethenolysis of cyclic olefins towards the goal of selectively forming α,ω-diene using cis-cyclooctene as a prototypical substrate. Dissymmetry at the N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ligand was identified as a key parameter for controlling the selectivity. The best-performing catalyst bearing an N-CF3 group significantly outperformed the benchmark second-generation Grubbs catalyst in the ethenolysis of cis-cycloctene. Application of this optimal catalyst to the ethenolysis of various norbornenes allows the efficient synthesis of valuable diene intermediates in good yields. The obsd. ligand effect trends could be rationalized through univariate and multivariate parameter anal. involving steric and electronic factors of the NHC ligand in the form of the buried vol. and the 77Se NMR chem. shift, in particular the σyy component of the shielding tensor of [Se(NHC)] model compds., resp. Natural chem. shift anal. of this chem. shielding tensor shows that σyy probes the π-acceptor property of the NHC ligand, the key electronic parameter that drives the relative rate of degenerate metathesis and selectivity in ethenolysis with catalysts bearing dissym. NHC ligands.

We report the synthesis of ruthenium metathesis catalysts contg. unsym. N-trifluoromethyl NHC ligands. These complexes have been fully characterized, and a Ru-F interaction has been identified in the solid state by x-ray crystallog. anal. for three catalysts with Ru-F distances between 2.629(2) and 2.652(2) Å. The influence of the N-trifluoromethyl NHC ligands on the initiation rates and activation parameters was studied. The activity of these catalysts was evaluated in benchmark olefin metathesis reactions and compared to the std. second-generation Grubbs catalyst. Remarkably, N-trifluoromethyl catalysts display an unusually high selectivity for the formation of terminal olefins (up to 90%) in the ethenolysis of Et oleate. Much improved selectivity is demonstrated for alternating copolymn. of cyclooctene and norbornene as well. These results underline the importance of electronic effects exerted by the NHC ligand.

Miyazaki, Hiroshi; Herbert, Myles B.; Liu, Peng; Dong, Xiaofei; Xu, Xiufang; Keitz, Benjamin K.; Ung, Thay; Mkrtumyan, Garik; Houk, K. N.; Grubbs, Robert H.
